bibl.title: Letter from Frank R. McCoy to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 31, 1928

div1.p: McCoy comments on Gen. Summerall's statements about the roles of Sternberg and Wood with regard to the yellow fever commission.

div1.head: Letter from Frank R. McCoy to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 31, 1928
div1.opener:
Col. Frank McCoy-
File II
LEGATION OF THE
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
Managua, Nicaragua,
March 31, 1928.
APR 17 1928
Colonel Jefferson R. Kean,
The Association of Military Surgeons of the U. S.,
7th and B Streets, S. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Kean:
div1.p:
Your letter of February 24th has followed me all
around Robinhood's Barn, and in the same mail I received
the New York Times containing a very fine address of General
Summerall on the military career of General Wood. It quite
disturbedstirred up my feelings and filled me with pride and pleasure.

In reply to your query about certain statements
made by the General in his address, I think both of General
Summerall's statements are correct, to this extent as regards
the appointment and sending of the Sternberg Board. The
initiative probably was with General Sternberg, but I do
know that General Wood talked with him about it and urged
the importance of such a work on two occasions when he was
in Washington while still Governor of Santiago; and I also
know, as you do, how thoroughly General Wood supported and
encouraged the work of that Board after he became Governor
General. I am not sure, however, that you will remember
that at one period, without consultation with the Governor
General, General Sternberg ordered this Board to complete
this work and return to Washington. That Dr. Reed came to
General
- 2 -
General Wood in great distress about it, and as you would
imagine General Wood took it up so vigorously with the De-
partment and personally with Mr. Root that General Sternberg
relented and the Board finished its greatwork with sufficient
time to do it right.

General Wood had a light case of yellow fever either
in August or September of 1898 while Military Governor of the
city of Santiago. I think it was during the period when
General Lawton was Military Governor of the province and
General Wood Military Governor of the city. I was not with
him at the time, but I do know that he had a written certifi-
cate which gave the facts and established his immunity, for
in after years, when he was Governor General, I accompanied
him to the United States several times when I was obliged to
undergo quarantine as a non-immune and he was passed in at
once on a certificate of immunity.

I had hoped to spend the next few months in the
United States, but conditions here are such that the Secretary
of State has asked me to remain on the spot, so that I shall
probably not be in Washington until late in the year. Frances
and I often talk about you and Mrs. Kean, and she joins me in
love and best wishes.
